results:
Based on my search results, I can provide information about F. Scott Fitzgerald's reputation in Polish literature and literary criticism:

## F. Scott Fitzgerald's Reception in Polish Literature

F. Scott Fitzgerald's works gained recognition in Poland as chronicles of the Jazz Age, and several collections of his short stories have been published in Poland, including "Historia jednego wyjazdu" (1962), "Odwiedziny w Babilonie" (1963), "Piękność Południa i inne opowiadania" (1981), "Popołudnie pisarza i inne opowiadania" (1989), and "Ciekawy przypadek Benjamina Buttona i inne opowiadania" (2008).

His letters to his daughter were also published in Poland under the title "Francis Scott Fitzgerald. Listy do córki" (1982).

## Polish Critical Reception

Fitzgerald is recognized in Poland as one of the leading representatives of the Lost Generation of American writers, whose work expressed disappointment and anarchic rebellion of young Americans against the post-World War I reality.

Polish critics view him as someone who, more than his great contemporaries like Hemingway and Faulkner, became the chronicler of the American "Lost Generation" – a generation whose start in life coincided with World War I.

### Reception of "The Great Gatsby"

The Polish reception of "The Great Gatsby" is varied:

F. Scott Fitzgerald in "The Great Gatsby" achieved something absolutely extraordinary: he created a work that not only stood the test of time but gained the status of a universal masterpiece, one of the most important novels of the 20th century.

Polish readers and critics describe it as "a multidimensional story about the American dream, about fascination with wealth and illusions, about loneliness in the crowd and the tragedy of conscious life".

Critics praise Fitzgerald's style as "deeply lyrical, sensual, filled with images of almost poetic texture. The author doesn't just describe events, he paints them. His sentences have rhythm and melody, are saturated with nostalgia and admiration for the transience of the moment".

However, there are also more critical voices:

Some readers question why the book has been proclaimed a classic, while others find it boring with unengaging characters and storylines.

There are many opinions both positive and critical about the novel, showing that Polish reception remains divided.

### Contemporary Polish Literary Scholarship

While the search results don't reveal specific names of Polish literary critics who have written extensively about Fitzgerald, they do show that Polish critics view "The Great Gatsby" as a work that should be studied through psychoanalytic methods, considering it more as a certain imagination or metaphor rather than a literal story.

The works continue to be republished and studied in Poland, indicating ongoing interest in Fitzgerald's literature among Polish readers and scholars, though specific critical studies by named Polish critics were not found in these search results.
